item.title: Australia Says It Will Join Airstrikes Against Islamic State in Iraq
item.description: Prime Minister Tony Abbott said on Friday that special operations personnel would also be deployed in Iraq. He ruled out airstrikes in Syria for now.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By MICHELLE INNIS

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Another U.S. University Severs Ties to Confucius Institute
item.description: Penn State’s decision follows a similar move by the University of Chicago, delivering a fresh setback to China’s soft-power push on American college campuses.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS and JESS MACY YU
item.media:credit: Nathan Weber for The New York Times
item.media:description: The campus of the University of Chicago, which last week suspended negotiations to renew its agreement with the Confucius Institute, a learning network sponsored by the Chinese government.

item.title: Ebola Strikes NBC News Cameraman in Liberia
item.description: The man, said to be a 33-year-old American, was working as a freelancer with a team in Liberia; he is to be flown to the United States for treatment.
item.dc:creator: By BILL CARTER

item.title: U.S. Eases Embargo on Arms to Vietnam
item.description: The United States partially lifted its ban on providing lethal arms to Vietnam, a move intended to help Hanoi strengthen its maritime security against China.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: Pham Binh Minh, Vietnam's foreign minister, met with U.S. officials in Washington on Thursday.

item.title: After Deadly Blast, Bulgaria Asks if Arms Disposal Is Worth It
item.description: The explosions took place in one of the poorest areas of Bulgaria, which is the European Union’s most impoverished member.
item.dc:creator: By GEORGI KANTCHEV
item.media:description: Bulgarian Red Cross members with relatives of workers killed Wednesday in an explosion at a munitions-dismantling plan.

item.title: 97 Soldiers Face Charges in Nigeria
item.description: Those charged, including 16 officers, are accused of mutiny, assault, cowardice and refusing to fight Islamic insurgents.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: North Korea Ready to Start Nuclear Talks
item.description: A senior North Korean envoy said Thursday that his country was ready to resume six-party talks on its nuclear program.
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: U.S. Effort to Help Liberia Finds Much Work to Do Before It Gets Started
item.description: The American promise to build 18 Ebola treatment centers has been stalled by, among other things, broken equipment and numerous holes on a runway.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By HELENE COOPER
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: While a United States delegation was visiting, Liberian workers were constructing the frame for a 300-bed Ebola treatment center Wednesday in Monrovia.

item.title: World Briefing: Greece: Officials Say They Uncovered a Terrorist Plot
item.description: Greek authorities said Thursday that they had thwarted a terrorist attack planned for Saturday, possibly against political or business targets.
item.dc:creator: By NIKI KITSANTONIS

item.title: World Briefing: Venezuela: Lawmaker Killed in His Home, Police Say
item.description: A day after Robert Serra, a rising star in Venezuela’s governing party, was stabbed to death in his home, officials said Thursday that it was a carefully planned murder.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Libya: Islamist Militias Batter Soldiers Near Benghazi
item.description: At least 13 Libyan soldiers were killed and more than 70 were wounded Thursday in car bombings and clashes with Islamists near the airport in the eastern city of Benghazi, military officials said.
item.dc:creator: By AGENCE FRANCE-PRESSE

item.title: Split Up by Holocaust, Top Collection of Yiddish Works Will Reunite Digitally
item.description: The YIVO Institute for Jewish Research, now in Manhattan, and the Lithuanian government have agreed to let the surviving YIVO documents in Lithuania be integrated into a web portal.
item.dc:creator: By JOSEPH BERGER
item.media:credit: Michael Appleton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jonathan Brent, the executive director of the YIVO Institute for Jewish Research, in the institute’s archives in Manhattan.

item.title: Ebola Patient’s Journey Shows How Global Travel Spreads Disease
item.description: Some experts say the system, relying heavily on the honesty of travelers and the diligence of airport workers, could quickly be overwhelmed by rapidly spreading disease.
item.dc:creator: By NORIMITSU ONISHI and JAD MOUAWAD

item.title: Some Hong Kong Residents, Weary of Disruptions, Find Fault With Protesters’ Methods
item.description: The mostly young people of the so-called Umbrella Revolution have found uneven support among middle-age and older people.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: A street in Hong Kong’s main financial district on Tuesday. Large parts of the city are shut down.

item.title: Turkey Votes to Allow Operations Against ISIS
item.description: Parliament also voted Thursday to allow foreign forces to launch operations from Turkey, but it was far from clear if the political step would soon translate into military action.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By CEYLAN YEGINSU
item.media:description: Turkish soldiers near the Syrian border at the town of Suruc on Thursday.

item.title: Shlomo Lahat, Ex-Mayor of Tel Aviv, Dies at 86
item.description: As mayor of Tel Aviv for almost two decades, Mr. Lahat presided over the city’s transformation into a vibrant and open urban center.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Open Source: Hong Kong Protesters Divided Over Use of Traffic as a Weapon
item.description: Despite appeals from their young leaders, some protesters in Hong Kong tried to escalate their clash with the authorities by blocking a main road.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Mideast Virus MERS Merits Caution, Not Alarm, W.H.O. Says
item.description: The announcement coincided with the annual Muslim pilgrimage to Mecca. The report suggested precautions for travelers to Saudi Arabia to minimize risk of exposure to MERS.
item.dc:creator: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.

item.title: Hong Kong Leader Refuses to Resign, but Deputy Meets With Protesters
item.description: Leung Chun-ying, the chief executive, said any talks with protest leaders would be within the parameters of Beijing’s blueprint for political change in Hong Kong.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY and KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: Putin Trumpets Economic Strength, but Advisers Seem Less Certain
item.description: Though the president depicted the Russian economy as open and stable, senior officials acknowledged slow growth and the flight of foreign investors.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin during a business conference on Thursday.

item.title: Protests Erupt in Homs Over Bombings That Killed Dozens of Syrian Schoolchildren
item.description: The demonstrators were supporters of the government, but angry that security forces did not prevent the attacks on a school that killed several dozen children in the Akrama district.
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD and MOHAMMAD GHANNAM

item.title: Hong Kong and Tiananmen Protests Have Major Differences
item.description: While the Chinese flag flies over Hong Kong, the demonstrations there spring from a very different political system.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: In New Front Against Islamic State, Dictionary Becomes a Weapon
item.description: Muslim groups in Europe and beyond are lashing out at the group in protests and on social media, advocating alternative ways to refer to the militants.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: Muslims attended a gathering outside the Great Mosque of Paris last month to protest against the group known as the Islamic State.

item.title: Memo From Seoul: Ferry Disaster That United South Korea Now Polarizes It
item.description: As grieving families continue their demands for a full inquiry into the April disaster, the president’s supporters have started to criticize them.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Mikhail Khodorkovsky, Ex-Oil Tycoon, Plans to Lead Political Movement
item.description: Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, who once led the Yukos oil company, vows to lead a drive to counter Putinism but has not yet dared to return to Russia.
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER
item.media:description: Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky during a meeting with students in Kiev, Ukraine, earlier this year.
